rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you. See [[WP:FIXNF]] and [[WP:10CR]]
rev.diff:
Line 5: Line 5:
==Generation Wave==
==Generation Wave==
â
[[File:Generation Wave logo.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Generation Wave logo]]
 
Following the [[2007 Burmese anti-government protests|2007 uprising]] against the [[State Peace and Development Council]], Burma's military rulers, Yan Yan Chan's bandmate Zayar Thaw helped found the pro-democracy youth movement [[Generation Wave]].<ref name="Irrawaddy"/> Though not an original founder, Yan Yan Chan became involved in the group as well.<ref name="Mizzima">{{cite web |url=http://www.mizzima.com/news/inside-burma/1512-detained-hip-hop-singer-yan-yan-chan-released.html |title=Detained Hip Hop singer Yan Yan Chan released |author=Than Htike Oo |date=7 January 2009 |work= |publisher=Mizzima News |accessdate=8 May 2011}}</ref> Generation Wave used graffiti and pamphlets to spread messages opposing the SPDC.<ref name="Irrawaddy"/> and distributed bumper stickers reading "Change New Government" to apply to cars carrying "CNG" stickers (originally for "compressed natural gas").<ref name="Irrawaddy"/> The group also circulated anti-government films, including [[Rambo IV]],<ref name="AAPP">{{cite web |url=http://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:elD48Vpaw3kJ:www.fbppn.net/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/Zayar_Thaw_updated_29June09.pdf+Zayar+thaw+AAPP&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEEShKj5EAUwNvhS8TgWkCItbnbL7neJnxI1MUDU0gQCvV349q_xJBEufb2nsMGJ74qTlH9dsbtrpS_-sAI3Sk5fQmxD4HkmSywBoSDMEEK6t5wnyLClFWq5xp_Cj49Ire2b9w5HJ7&sig=AHIEtbShPsRNV_Xy7Un_jusqrH3bX2j6rw |title=AAPP Case No. 0062 |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Assistance Association for Political Prisoners |accessdate=7 May 2011}}</ref> in which the titular character battles [[Tatmadaw]] (Burmese military) soldiers in [[Karen State]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.burmacampaign.org.uk/index.php/news-and-reports/news-stories/Rambo-Draws-World-Attention-to-Forgotten-Crisis-in-Burma |title=Rambo Draws Worldâs Attention to Forgotten Crisis in Burma |author= |date=12 Feb 2008 |work= |publisher=Burma Campaign UK |accessdate=7 May 2011}}</ref> The film had been banned by the government for portraying the SPDC and its soldiers in a negative light.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1579082/Banned-Rambo-film-hot-property-in-Burma.html |title=Banned Rambo film hot property in Burma |author=Thomas Bell |date=18 February 2008 |work= |publisher=''The Telegraph'' |accessdate=7 May 2011}}</ref>
Following the [[2007 Burmese anti-government protests|2007 uprising]] against the [[State Peace and Development Council]], Burma's military rulers, Yan Yan Chan's bandmate Zayar Thaw helped found the pro-democracy youth movement [[Generation Wave]].<ref name="Irrawaddy"/> Though not an original founder, Yan Yan Chan became involved in the group as well.<ref name="Mizzima">{{cite web |url=http://www.mizzima.com/news/inside-burma/1512-detained-hip-hop-singer-yan-yan-chan-released.html |title=Detained Hip Hop singer Yan Yan Chan released |author=Than Htike Oo |date=7 January 2009 |work= |publisher=Mizzima News |accessdate=8 May 2011}}</ref> Generation Wave used graffiti and pamphlets to spread messages opposing the SPDC.<ref name="Irrawaddy"/> and distributed bumper stickers reading "Change New Government" to apply to cars carrying "CNG" stickers (originally for "compressed natural gas").<ref name="Irrawaddy"/> The group also circulated anti-government films, including [[Rambo IV]],<ref name="AAPP">{{cite web |url=http://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:elD48Vpaw3kJ:www.fbppn.net/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/Zayar_Thaw_updated_29June09.pdf+Zayar+thaw+AAPP&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEEShKj5EAUwNvhS8TgWkCItbnbL7neJnxI1MUDU0gQCvV349q_xJBEufb2nsMGJ74qTlH9dsbtrpS_-sAI3Sk5fQmxD4HkmSywBoSDMEEK6t5wnyLClFWq5xp_Cj49Ire2b9w5HJ7&sig=AHIEtbShPsRNV_Xy7Un_jusqrH3bX2j6rw |title=AAPP Case No. 0062 |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Assistance Association for Political Prisoners |accessdate=7 May 2011}}</ref> in which the titular character battles [[Tatmadaw]] (Burmese military) soldiers in [[Karen State]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.burmacampaign.org.uk/index.php/news-and-reports/news-stories/Rambo-Draws-World-Attention-to-Forgotten-Crisis-in-Burma |title=Rambo Draws Worldâs Attention to Forgotten Crisis in Burma |author= |date=12 Feb 2008 |work= |publisher=Burma Campaign UK |accessdate=7 May 2011}}</ref> The film had been banned by the government for portraying the SPDC and its soldiers in a negative light.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1579082/Banned-Rambo-film-hot-property-in-Burma.html |title=Banned Rambo film hot property in Burma |author=Thomas Bell |date=18 February 2008 |work= |publisher=''The Telegraph'' |accessdate=7 May 2011}}</ref>
